channel.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
channel.description:
I want to make a similar website to this. https://skinarena.com/ I still don't understand how they do this, I've made a version but I think people would be able tamper with the data that is sent to the server through the client. How do they do this because i've looked through their javascript and I can't seem to find anything to do with sockets. I noticed they are SSL encrypted.
How would I go about making this kind of website which would disable hackers(hackz0rz) from tampering with that data which is being sent to the server.
Cheers.

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

Death Style:

not knowing how skin arena works, I dunno a situation where you wouldn’t just verify the data on the backend.

This is essentially what the OP needs to do.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @Death_Style Death Style
item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

not knowing how skin arena works, I dunno a situation where you wouldn’t just verify the data on the backend. I figured the question was asked because he wanted to verify the username wasn’t tampered with which oauth solves.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

Death Style:

his only example was a username. his server should still receive that and other sensitive information from a trusted source and not the client.

Right, but the problem is that the game’s data has to come from said client.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @Death_Style Death Style
item.description:
@Death_Style wrote:

his only example was a username. his server should still receive that and other sensitive information from a trusted source and not the client.

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Death Style, post:10, topic:551810”][quote author=Frantix link=topic=670726.msg4484952#msg4484952 date=1433410431]
Alright I understand that, so using something like this socket.emit('add user', username); This is sending the request add user from the client to the server. How does the website do this because when I look into there javascript files they have no sockets sending data.
[/quote]

Not sure what you’re specifically asking about. It looks like you sign in using your Steam account via oauth and from then you get a cookie that verifies your identity. It only knows your username from the response from the Steam server, not data sent by the client.

wat

what[/quote]

He’s talking about how to send data from a client (specifically the browser) to a server without the data being tampered/intercepted with… This question can extend beyond Steam.

Read full topic

what

item.description:

Yeah using oauth to authorize your steam account, you can make trades with their bots and from there everything is handled server sided.

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

No idea, but have you considered the fact that it might just be a standard ajax request?

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @Frantix Frantix
item.description:
@Frantix wrote:

Justin Bieber:

If you use public key encryption then your users can’t decrypt or tamper with the message unless they have the private key. However if they know the original message (or any valid message of their choice) then they can just encrypt this themselves and send that. But really what davidi said - you shouldn’t trust any message from the client, encrypted or not.

Alright I understand that, so using something like this socket.emit('add user', username); This is sending the request add user from the client to the server. How does the website do this because when I look into there javascript files they have no sockets sending data.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

If you use public key encryption then your users can’t decrypt or tamper with the message unless they have the private key. However if they know the original message (or any valid message of their choice) then they can just encrypt this themselves and send that. But really what davidi said - you shouldn’t trust any message from the client, encrypted or not.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Yea, you never trust the client side to be secure. You do your verification server sided.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript - Tampering with data
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

You need to verify the data, encryption only secures safe transfer, not that the data isn’t tempered with.

Read full topic
